articles.headline: Putin’s Crackdown Leaves Transgender Russians Bracing for Worse
articles.snippet: A new law underscores how Vladimir V. Putin is increasingly using the war in Ukraine as justification for greater restrictions on L.G.B.T.Q. life, portraying it as a consequence of deviant Western values.
articles.abstract: A new law underscores how Vladimir V. Putin is increasingly using the war in Ukraine as justification for greater restrictions on L.G.B.T.Q. life, portraying it as a consequence of deviant Western values.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jan Dvorkin had raised and nurtured his adopted son in Moscow for seven years until, one day in May, the Russian authorities notified him they were revoking custody. A woman Mr. Dvorkin knew had filed an official complaint, saying that because he was transgender and gay, he was an unfit parent.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Georgy Birger

articles.headline: Biden Shores Up Democratic Support, but Faces Tight Race Against Trump
articles.snippet: A New York Times/Siena College poll found that President Biden is on stronger footing than he was a year ago — but he is neck-and-neck in a possible rematch against Donald Trump.
articles.abstract: A New York Times/Siena College poll found that President Biden is on stronger footing than he was a year ago — but he is neck-and-neck in a possible rematch against Donald Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden is heading into the 2024 presidential contest on firmer footing than a year ago, with his approval rating inching upward and once-doubtful Democrats falling into line behind his re-election bid, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein, Ruth Igielnik and Camille Baker

articles.headline: Planning to Visit Barcelona or Dubrovnik? It’s Going to Cost You.
articles.snippet: Driven by the climate crisis, the post-pandemic surge in visitors and a growing interest in making tourism work for local communities, European cities are finding new ways to tax visitors.
articles.abstract: Driven by the climate crisis, the post-pandemic surge in visitors and a growing interest in making tourism work for local communities, European cities are finding new ways to tax visitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Hester Van Buren, a deputy mayor of Amsterdam, recently proposed a 1 percentage point increase to the city’s tourist accommodation tax — which is already among the highest in Europe — her City Council colleagues responded with a single criticism: They wanted the increase to be even bigger.

articles.headline: Solar Supply Chain Grows More Opaque Amid Human Rights Concerns
articles.snippet: The global industry is cutting some ties to China, but its exposure to forced labor remains high and companies are less transparent, a new report found.
articles.abstract: The global industry is cutting some ties to China, but its exposure to forced labor remains high and companies are less transparent, a new report found.
articles.lead_paragraph: Global supply chains for solar panels have begun shifting away from a heavy reliance on China, in part because of a recent ban on products from Xinjiang, a region where the U.S. government and United Nations accuse the Chinese government of committing human rights violations.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Ivan Penn

articles.headline: A Craigslist for Guns, With No Background Checks
articles.snippet: A federal gun law passed last year gave the Biden administration a powerful new tool to increase background checks on “private” firearms sales. Will the administration use it?
articles.abstract: A federal gun law passed last year gave the Biden administration a powerful new tool to increase background checks on “private” firearms sales. Will the administration use it?
articles.lead_paragraph: Another school week had just begun at Central Visual and Performing Arts High School in St. Louis when Orlando Harris, armed with a recently purchased AR-15-style rifle and 600 rounds of ammunition, burst into the building with a declaration: “You are all going to die!”
articles.byline: By Serge F. Kovaleski and Glenn Thrush
